Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

ALLEGATION:
Facility has not submitted records to MDHHS for permanent retention one year
following the final order of adoption as required.
INVESTIGATION:
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on May 23,
2022. Chief Administrator stated the agency has attempted to send the adoption files
timely but at times there is not anyone available at some of the DHS offices to
accept the files. CA stated there has been some confusion regarding where and
when to send the adoption files. Initially, the backlog files were to be sent to Central
Office. CA stated their agency has a lot of adoption files and it was a timely process
to combine the adoption files along with the foster care files. CA stated each DHS
office has a different process for accepting the adoption files. CA stated the agency
will have the local DHS sign a document acknowledging receipt when they hand
deliver adoption files.
Adoption supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on May 23, 2022.
Adoption supervisor was provided details regarding the specific adoption files that
were not provided timely. Adoption supervisor stated she is almost certain that both
files were not provided to the local DHS offices timely. She stated Youth A’s file was
misplaced behind another file and not provided to DHS timely. Adoption supervisor
stated the agency tries to hand deliver files, if possible, but otherwise will send
2

certified mail. If files are hand delivered the agency will have the local DHS office
sign a document acknowledging receipt.
Documents Reviewed:
 Complainant provided information regarding specific adoption files that were
not submitted timely via email on May 23, 2022. MISACWIS Case File: Youth
A’s adoption finalization order was signed on October 12, 2020.
 Cover sheet agency hand delivered Youth A’s file to Mason/Oceana DHHS
on April 29, 2022. Mason/Oceana DHS staff signed acknowledging receipt of
the file on April 29, 2022.
 MISACWIS Case File: Youth B’s adoption finalization order was signed on
November 6, 2020.
 Cover sheet agency hand delivered Youth B’s file to Ottawa DHHS on May 5,
2022. Ottawa DHS staff signed acknowledging receipt of the file on May 5,
2022.
APPLICABLE RULE
ADM 1030 Adoption case record retention
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-Adoption Placement Record.
ANALYSIS: The agency is found in non-compliance as they did not send the
original adoption records to the local MDHHS office within 12-13
months after finalization of adoption as required.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
